question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
According to market research, the demand curve for a local pizza
restaurant satisfies the following relation: if \emph{p} is the price of
a pizza (in dollars), and \emph{q} is the number of pizzas sold per day,
then

\[\displaystyle
p^2 + 4q^2 = 800.\]

The restaurant owners want to determine what price the restaurant should
charge for each pizza in order to make their daily revenue as high as
possible.

\textbf{(b)} Use the method of Lagrange multipliers to solve the problem
in part
\textbf{\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH105/April_2012/Question_6_(a)}{(a)}}.
There is no need to justify that the solution you obtained is the
absolute maximum or minimum.

\textbf{A solution that does not use the method of Lagrange multipliers
will receive no credit, even if the answer is correct.}
sols:
We are maximizing $f(p,q) = pq$ subject to $g(p,q) = p^2 + 4q^2 = 800$.
Solving the constraint for zero we obtain
$h(p,q) = p^2 + 4q^2 - 800 = 0$, so that the Lagrange system is

\[\nabla f(p,q) = \lambda \nabla h(p,q)\]

Computing the gradients,

\[f_p = (pq)_p = q \qquad f_q = (pq)_q = p\] Also,

\[h_p = (p^2 + 4q^2)_p = 2p \qquad h_q = (p^2 + 4q^2)_q = 8q\]

Therefore,

\[\displaystyle
<q,p> = \lambda <2p, 8q>\] which gives us two equations, namely:

\begin{align*}
q &= 2 \lambda p \quad \text{(equation 1)} \\
p &= 8 \lambda q \quad \text{(equation 2)}
\end{align*}

In substituting $q = 2 \lambda p$ into $p = 8 \lambda q$, we get

\[\displaystyle
p = 8 \lambda (2 \lambda p) = 16 \lambda^2 p\]

We can factor this to find $p(1 - 16 \lambda^2) = 0$ so that either

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle p = 0$
\item
  $\displaystyle 1 - 16\lambda^2 = 0$, i.e. $\lambda = \pm 1/4$.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  If $p=0$ then $q = 2 \lambda (0) = 0$, and $p=q=0$ cannot satisfy the
  constraint. \textbf{We reject this case.}
\item
  If $\lambda = \pm 1/4$ then $q = 2 (\pm 1/4) p = \pm p/2$.
  Substituting this into the constraint gives:
\end{enumerate}

\[0 = p^2 + 4(\pm p/2)^2 -800 = 2p^2-800\] which mean
\emph{p}\textsuperscript{2} = 400, or $p=\pm20$.

We take the positive root (since price should be positive). At a price
of \$20 (with a demand of 10/day), the revenue is maximized.

\emph{Aside: it wouldn't make sense for either p or q to be 0 (there
would be no revenue), so we can safely divide the equations (1) and (2)
without the risk of dividing by 0. Or to look at it another way: if q =
0 then from the equations that forces p=0 (and vice versa), and p=q=0
could not satisfy the constraint. If we divide the equations then
$q/p = (2 \lambda p)/(8 \lambda q) = p/(4q)$. Cross-multiplying gives
the relation $p^2 = 4q^2$ which could be used in the constraint equation
to find p and q.}
hints:
Recall that the objective function is $f(p,q) = pq$, with contraint
$g(p,q) = p^2 + 4q^2 = 800$.

Solve the constraint equation for zero to obtain \emph{h(p,q)} and set
up the Lagrange system

\[\nabla f(p,q) = \lambda \nabla h(p,q)\] and \emph{h(p,q)} = 0. Now,
compute the partial derivatives of both sides with respect to the
variables, \emph{p} and \emph{q} to set up the system of equations that
need to be solved.
